messages.message: @jayasooryan Is it something we can programmatically find out? If so can we create a new PDF cos overlapping PDFs like are not useful anyway! It’s better to loose original backgrounds etc than creating this way!

Based on @Gaurav Saini’s analysis, the image itself contains text in addition to the invisible machine readable text here. Identifying whether the image portion also contains text won't be an easy task. But again, this looks like a unique edge case. I'm not sure why the PDF contain text in image as well as in an invisible layer. If the text was only in the image, we would have considered it as a scanned document and performed OCR, which won't have overlapping texts.

We can also do force image OCR always. But that's wasteful for regular machine readable PDFs in terms of time & resource usage, as well as the quality of the translated PDF output (it's easier to preserve styles in a machine readable PDFs).

@jayasooryan for doc translation do we use `extract_all_layers` ? If yes, then we can detect such pdfs by comparing the bounding boxes of OCR over image only pdfs and the ones from pdf text extraction to check if there's an overlap above some set threshold.

We currently don't use `extract_all_layers` in doc translation. Based on the IB documentation, this is going to run OCR on all the pages, even if the doc is machine readable. If this is a common scenario, then we need to fix this, and pick this up in the next iteration of doc translation app improvements. cc: @avi
Yup, it will run OCR for all pages but only for image elements in the page.
cc: @hannah to help prioritise. @Monette is this scenario for our admin, or for a customer?
